executive_summary: The industrial and fluid power valve manufacturing industry is grappling with escalating import penetration, largely fueled by competitive pricing from countries like China and Mexico. This trend has led to decreased demand for domestically produced valves. The widening price differential between domestic and imported valves, coupled with the industry's struggle with flat industrial production, has put pressure on the industry's performance and revenue streams. Overall, industry revenue is projected to decline at a CAGR of 1.4% through 2024, including a 1.8% decline in 2024 alone, to reach $26.3 billion.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Import Penetration Has Increasingly Challenged Domestic Manufacturers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Competitive pricing of imported valves driven by lower labor costs in exporting countries, primarily China and Mexico, has enabled them to offer products at more attractive price points than domestic counterparts, contributing to lower demand for domestically manufactured valves.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Flat Industrial Production Has Pressured Industry Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industrial production index, which measures the output from the mining, manufacturing, electric and gas industries, has experienced little growth overall during the current period, with industrial production remaining largely at the levels seen in 2019.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Domestic Manufacturers Historically Excelled in Innovation
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Historically, valve manufacturers in the United States have maintained a competitive edge through their commitment to innovation, which has spurred growing demand from international markets, driving growth and profitability.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Increased Commodity Prices Have Lifted Valve Prices
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Valves are predominantly from a range of metals, including iron and steel. The prices of these materials are subject to fluctuations in the commodities market. When the costs of input materials rise, it typically results in increased valve prices.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Input Costs Are Projected to Decline
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The price of iron and steel is expected to decline in the first half of the outlook period, driven by global demand and supply factors. As the price of key inputs declines, valve manufacturers will face additional challenges in keeping prices high.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: As the Economy Adjusts From High Interest Rates
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While interest rates are expected to decline slightly by the end of 2024, the Federal Reserve is anticipated to take more aggressive measures beginning in 2025, resulting in lower interest rates and facilitating economic expansion.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: While Domestic Demand Is Set to Rise
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As industrial production expands, domestic valve manufacturers are projected to boost their output to meet the rising demand for their products. Yet, a portion of the extra domestic demand will be met by foreign manufacturers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Domestic Manufacturers Will Emphasize Efficiency and Safety
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The development of efficient designs will remain crucial, as domestic valve manufacturers seek to optimize the functionality and operational efficiency of their products. This entails technologies such as automation, digital monitoring systems, and energy-efficient designs.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures industrial and fluid power (hydraulic and pneumatic) valves, other flow control devices and related parts, including assemblies, couplings and fittings. Valves are integral to a broad range of industrial and general applications, including manufacturing, waterworks and energy. Residential plumbing fixtures, trim and general-purpose valves and fittings are not included in this industry.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers: Industrial production index

key_trends: The valve manufacturing industry typically has lower capital expenditures as a percentage of revenue than the broader fabricated metal manufacturing sector.
The plumbing fixture fitting and trim segment is more concentrated, with the top four players controlling more than half of all sales in the segment.
The valve manufacturing industry exhibits a more consolidated market in the fluid power valve segment, highlighting a more consolidated market compared to the industrial valve segment.
The industrial valve segment has experienced the lowest and declining concentration, attributed to increased competition from international players.

The growing prevalence of imported valves underscores a shift in market dynamics, signaling a need for domestic manufacturers to reevaluate their operational approaches in order to maintain relevance and competitiveness.
Demand for valves is expected to increase in the coming years, as the economy normalizes from the high interest rate environment.
Parker Hannifin introduced Hi-Pro Series ball valves in November 2023, designed to improve operational efficiency and reliability for hydrogen applications.
Emerson's launch of the ASCOTM Series 262 and 263 Biodiesel Valves in February 2023 represents a technological advancement.
The stability of economic growth in foreign markets is crucial, given that exports account for more than one-third of the valve manufacturing industry's total revenue.

The industrial production index is a crucial determinant of demand within the industry, as it measures the pulse of economic activity in sectors such as mining, manufacturing, electricity, oil and gas.
While dramatic rises in the price of steel have enabled valve manufacturers to achieve greater revenue growth, it has come at the cost of larger expenses and less profit in certain years.
Purchase costs are primarily driven by input commodities, most commonly steel, zinc, nickel and aluminum.

The Gulf Coast region serves as a prominent hub for valve manufacturers, catering to the oil and gas industry due to the area's concentration of refineries, chemical plants, and offshore installations.
Valve manufacturers find success in areas such as Texas and California, which are highly populous and benefit from their proximity to Mexico.
Industrial valve manufacturers must stay updated on trends in the oil and gas, chemical processing, power generation and manufacturing sectors.
Demand for plumbing fixture fittings and trim is intricately linked to the housing market and overall construction sector trends.
The focus on energy efficiency and sustainability in commercial construction is increasing demand for advanced valves.
